questions.question:
Question 1: If histopathological examination of a 2-day-old forearm laceration is done, which of the 
following would be seen?
questions.explanation:
Neutrophil peak is seen on day 2 of the inflammatory phase of wound healing. Wound healing has three phases: The inflammatory phase, proliferative phase, and maturation 
phase. The inflammatory phase lasts 2-3 days. 1094 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 2: A patient's wound has the given appearance 1 week after the injury. Which cells are 
predominantly found in this stage of wound healing?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows granulation tissue formed during the proliferative stage of wound healing. 
Fibroblasts are the predominant cell during the proliferative stage. Fibroblasts are specialized cells that differentiate from resting mesenchymal cells into connective 
tissue. The primary function of fibroblasts is to synthesize collagen. The proliferative stage of wound healing is characterized by the formation of granulation tissue, 
which consists of a capillary bed, fibroblasts, macrophages, and a loose arrangement of collagen, 
fibronectin, and hyaluronic acid.

questions.question:
Question 3: 1082 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following is an anti-inflammatory cytokine involved in wound healing?
questions.explanation:
Interleukins 1, 6 and 8 are pro-inflammatory cytokines, whereas IL-10 is an anti-inflammatory 
cytokine.

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following events of wound healing will be altered in a patient with scurvy?
questions.explanation:
Dietary deficiency of vitamin C (scurvy) results in poorly formed collagen and affects the early 
matrix scaffolding. Type I and Type III collagens are both present in the extracellular matrix of normal skin (in an 8:1 
ratio). However, during the proliferative phase of wound healing, the dominant collagen that is 
laid is Type III. This stage is also known as early matrix scaffolding. Type III collagen is gradually 
replaced by type I collagen (during the final remodeling phase) until a ratio (type I: type III) of 4:1 
is achieved. 1095 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 5: In patients presenting with non-healing surgical incisions, what is the most common 
underlying cause?
questions.explanation:
All the factors listed impair wound healing, but local infection is the most common underlying 
cause of non-healing surgical incisions. To reduce the chances of infection ,the surgeon should make every effort to remove all devitalized 
tissue and leave a clean wound for closure. Factors affecting wound healing: • Site of the wound • Structures involved • Mechanism of wounding (crushing, incision, avulsion) • Contamination • Loss of tissue • Local factors (vascularity, previous irradiation, pressure) • Systemic factors (malnutrition, anemia, steroids, AIDS, smoking)

questions.question:
Question 6: A child with a grazed knee comes to your clinic for first aid. He has a history of nephrotic 
syndrome and is on oral prednisolone therapy. Which stage of wound healing would be most 
affected by his medication?
questions.explanation:
While all of the given options are inhibited by steroids, the major effect of steroids is to inhibit the 
initial inflammatory phase of wound healing (angiogenesis, neutrophil and macrophage 
migration, and fibroblast proliferation) and the release of lysosomal enzymes. The stronger the anti-inflammatory effect of the steroid compound used, the greater the inhibitory 
effect on wound healing. Steroids used after the first 3 to 4 days post-injury do not affect wound 
healing as severely as when they are used in the immediate postoperative period. In addition to inhibiting collagen synthesis, steroids also inhibit epithelialization and contraction 
and contribute to increased rates of wound infection, regardless of the time of administration. Steroid delayed healing of cutaneous wounds can be stimulated to epithelialize by topical 
application of vitamin A.

questions.question:
Question 7: Which of the following findings in a long-standing ulcer would indicate malignant 
transformation?
questions.explanation:
Everted edge around a chronic wound is a sign of malignant transformation. The majority of wounds that have not healed in 3 months are considered chronic and are prone to 
malignant changes. Malignant wounds are differentiated clinically from non-malignant wounds by 
the presence of overturned edges. Biopsy of the wound edges should be performed to rule out 
malignancy. Malignant transformation can occur in any long-standing wound. The image shows a Marjolin's 
ulcer with everted edges. It is squamous cell carcinoma that develops on a long-standing burn. 1096 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 8: A 21-year-old man came to the casualty 12 hours after sustaining a laceration on his leg from 
a trekking accident. On closer examination, other than dirt, you do not notice any pus or 
signs of infection. What is the most appropriate management?

options.a: Closure after granulation tissue has formed
options.b: Delayed closure 2 days after removal of devitalised tissue
options.c: Primary closure after adequate wound toileting and debridement
options.d: Wound debridement, topical antibiotics and dressing

questions.explanation:
Contaminated wounds older than 6 hours should be managed with delayed primary closure. The wound is cleaned, debrided, and left open for a few days. This allows soft tissues to drain and 
also ensures no infection is present before surgical closure can be done. Wound closure is categorized into primary, secondary, or tertiary: Primary closure is done for clean wounds with minimal tissue loss that are amenable to 
approximation of wound edges. Healing occurs by primary intention. Primary closure is ideally 
performed within 6 to 8 hrs of trauma, but wounds in vascular areas (e.g. face) may be delayed to 
up to 24 hours after trauma. Secondary closure allows healing by secondary intention. The wound is left open to heal largely by 
the formation of granulation tissue and contraction. These wounds often have significant tissue 
loss precluding tension-free approximation of edges, with devitalized edges. Wound dressings are 
changed daily to aid in the formation of granulation tissue and subsequent contraction. Tertiary closure, also known as delayed primary closure, results in a combination of healing by 
primary and secondary intention. The wound is thoroughly irrigated, debrided, and left open for 2 
to 5 days before surgical closure. It is used for wounds that are grossly contaminated without 
significant tissue loss.

questions.question:
Question 9: Stage the bedsore in the following image: 1084 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given image shows complete skin loss that involves muscles and shows exposed bone 
indicating a stage 4 pressure sore. Pressure sores are skin or soft tissue injuries that occur due to prolonged pressure over specific 
areas of the body. An external pressure of >30 mmHg leads to the formation of pressure sores. 1097 
Sold by @itachibot The common sites of pressure sores in decreasing frequency are the ischium, greater trochanter, 
sacrum, heel, malleolus (lateral followed by medial), and occiput. Pressure sores can be prevented with good skincare, the use of air-fluidized beds, special 
pressure-dispersion cushions, or foams. Repositioning the patient every two hours can lessen the 
pressure on the area. Ulcers of stages 1 and 2 often do not require operative measures. They are managed with regular 
wound cleaning and dressing with a good antibiotic cover. Stage 3 and 4 ulcers are adequately debrided, and vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) is used to 
promote the growth of granulation tissue required for surgical closure. Large skin flaps that have 
muscle with sensory innervation are best for reconstruction.

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following is the most common site of pressure sores ?
questions.explanation: Pressure sore frequency in descending order: • Ischium • Greater Trochanter • Sacrum • Heel • Malleolus • Occiput

questions.question:
Question 11: An elderly paraplegic patient admitted to a nursing home, developed an ulcer on her gluteal 
region. All of the following are true regarding the management of this patient except: 1085 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: Diet and nutritional support should aim to establish a positive nitrogen balance
options.b: Following debridement, exposure of the wound is recommended
options.c: Tensor fascia lata flap with an intact nerve supply may be used for covering the defect
options.d: Frequent change in position and air mattresses can help in preventing further sores

questions.explanation:
The given image is that of a grade 3 bedsore. A grade 3 pressure sore requires dressing following 
debridement. Preoperative management involves adequate debridement, and the use of vacuum-assisted closure 
(VAC) to provide a suitable wound for surgical closure. Alginates, foams, hydrocolloids, hydrogels 
are other options that are available. The aim of surgery is to fill the dead space and to provide durable sensate skin. Large skin flaps 
that include muscle are best and, occasionally, an intact sensory innervated area can be included 
(e.g. extensor fascia lata flap with the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh). Nutritional optimization with high caloric and protein diet should be done to establish a positive 
nitrogen balance. Frequent changes in position and air mattresses can also help in preventing 
further sores.

questions.question:
Question 12: A meshed skin graft was used to cover a defect and vacuum-assisted closure of the transplant 
was done. What is the pressure generated within the dressing?
questions.explanation:
The pressure used in vacuum-assisted closure for wound healing is –125 mmHg. 1098 
Sold by @itachibot Applying negative pressure appears to hasten debridement and the formation of granulation 
tissue in chronic wounds and ulcers. It acts by decreasing edema, by removing interstitial fluid, and as a result, helps in decreasing 
bacterial counts and cell proliferation increases.

questions.question:
Question 13: A man who had undergone an exploratory laparotomy 6 months ago came for a follow-up 
visit. Which of the following statements about healed incision is false?

options.a: Disorganized collagen fibers become aligned along stress lines
options.b: Strength of the scar is in their weave rather than in their amount
options.c: By the first week it is held by sutures and a weak type 3 collagen matrix
options.d: Tensile strength is about 60-80% of normal skin by 3 months

questions.explanation:
During the first week, a surgical wound has minimal inherent strength because the dermal edges 
are held together solely by a hemostatic plug and sutures. During the second postoperative week, fibroblasts proliferate rapidly and begin to produce type I 
collagen in addition to type III. The strength of the wound is still limited to less than 10% of its 
final strength. By week 6, the concentration of strong collagen fibers begins to resemble that of 
intact skin. As the collagen matures and becomes denser, the scar becomes almost acellular as the fibroblasts 
and blood vessels reduce.The disorganized collagen fibers become aligned along stress lines with 
their strength being in their weave rather than in their amount. Most of these changes occur over the first three months but a scar will continue to mature for 1 to 
2 years. Tensile strength will continue to increase but would not be expected to exceed 60–80% of 
that of normal skin.

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following statements are true with regards to a keloid scar?

options.a: The extent does not cross the wound margins
options.b: Wide excision of the keloid scar prevents recurrence
options.c: Histopathology of a keloid scar shows reduced collagen and increased vascularity
options.d: A keloid scar forms due to increase in the level of growth factors

questions.explanation:
Keloid scars are associated with elevated levels of growth factor leading to increased proliferation 
of fibrous tissue. A keloid scar is defined as excessive scar tissue that extends beyond the boundaries of the original 
incision or wound (option A) and rarely regresses on its own. It is more common in 
darker-pigmented ethnicities. It can arise from surgery, burns, skin inflammation, infections, ear piercing, and even 
spontaneously. It occurs 3 months to years after the initial insult with even minor injuries causing 
keloid formation. It most commonly occurs on the skin of the earlobe, deltoid, presternal, upper back, and rarely 
extends into the subcutaneous tissue. The histology of keloid scars shows excess collagen and hypervascularity with collagen fibres 
arranged haphazardly in loose sheets (option C). Treatment: Keloid scars do not improve spontaneously with time and excision alone has a high 
rate of recurrence (option B). The following can be done: 1100 
Sold by @itachibot • Pressure - local moulds or elastic garments. • Silicone gel sheeting. • Intralesional triamcinolone injection. • Excision and steroid injections. • Excision and postoperative radiation (external beam or brachytherapy). • Intralesional excision. • Laser to reduce redness. • Vitamin E and palm oil massage. questions.question:
Question 16: A patient has been treated for the lesion shown in the picture below for the past 12 months 
but there has been no response to treatment. What is the next line of treatment for this 
patient? 1088 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Surgical excision in combination with adjuvant therapy is advised to patients with refractory 
keloids. The adjuvant therapy usually includes radiation.The risk of malignancy attributable to keloid 
radiation therapy is minimal Treatment of keloids : • First-line treatments include silicones in combination with pressure therapy and intralesional 
corticosteroid injections. 1101 
Sold by @itachibot • Intralesional 5-fluorouracil, bleomycin, and verapamil should be used in accordance with 
established treatment protocols. • Refractory cases after 12 months of therapy should be considered for surgical excision in 
combination with adjuvant therapy. • Excision alone results in a high recurrence rate of 50% to 100% and enlargement of the keloid. • Immediate postoperative electron beam irradiation or brachytherapy with iridium-192 reduces 
recurrence rates. The risk of malignancy attributable to keloid radiation therapy is minimal. • An additional new invasive treatment modality is internal cryotherapy, in which a metal rod is 
introduced into the keloid and the subsequent extreme cooling leads to tissue necrosis.

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following techniques will you use to reduce suture marks and scars?
questions.explanation:
Fine sutures (6/0 or smaller) placed close to the wound margins tend to cause less 
scarring. Subcuticular suturing avoids suture marks on either side of the wound or incision. Suture marks can be minimized using monofilament sutures that are removed early (3–5 days). 
Wounds can be strengthened post-suture removal by the use of sticky strips.

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following is not a skin substitute?
questions.explanation:
Duoderm is a hydrocolloid and not a skin substitute. Skin substitutes are skin products made of cells, extracellular matrix components, or a 
combination of the two. Integra is a bilayered membrane skin substitute. Alloderm is a acellular cadaveric dermis. Apligraf is a living bilayered biologic dressing composed of neonatal dermal fibroblasts on a 
collagen matrix. Trancyte is a tissue-engineered skin substitute is made from a nylon mesh and a silastic 
semi-permissible and biocompatible layer.

questions.question: Question 19: Identify the procedure shown in the image.
questions.explanation:
The image depicts a fasciotomy of the lower limb. Fasciotomy involves incising the deep muscle fascia and is best carried out via longitudinal 
incisions of skin, fat, and fascia. The muscle is seen bulging out through the fasciotomy opening. The lower limb can be decompressed via two incisions, each being lateral to the subcutaneous 
border of the tibia. This gives access to the two posterior compartments and to the peroneal and 
anterior compartments of the leg. 1102 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 20: A catheter is inserted into the limb of a patient suspected to have compartment syndrome. 
What minimum reading on the pressure monitor will prompt an immediate fasciotomy?
questions.explanation:
The pressure threshold for doing a fasciotomy in a case of suspected compartment syndrome is 30 
mmHg Fasciotomy involves incising the deep muscle fascia and is best carried out via longitudinal 
incisions of skin, fat, and fascia.

questions.question: Question 21: While performing a fasciotomy for compartment syndrome, the following layers are incised:

options.c: Skin, Subcutaneous tissue, Superficial fascia and Deep fascia
options.d: Skin, Subcutaneous tissue, Superficial fascia, Deep fascia and a few muscular fibres

questions.explanation:
The incision for a fasciotomy involves the skin, subcutaneous tissue, superficial fascia, and deep 
fascia. Fasciotomy involves incising the deep muscle fascia and is best carried out via longitudinal 
incisions of skin, subcutaneous fat, and superficial and deep fascia. The muscle will be seen 
bulging out through the fasciotomy opening. The lower limb can be decompressed via two incisions, each being lateral to the subcutaneous 
border of the tibia. This gives access to the two posterior compartments and the leg's peroneal and 
anterior compartments.

questions.question: Question 22: The lower limb of this patient was run over by a car. Identify the type of injury.
questions.explanation:
Degloving injury occurs when the skin and subcutaneous fat are stripped by avulsion from its 
underlying fascia, leaving neurovascular structures, tendons, or bones exposed. It may be open or closed. 1103 
Sold by @itachibot A tidy wound is a clean incised wound with seldom tissue loss whereas an untidy wound is one 
that is crushed, avulsed, contaminated often with tissue loss.

questions.question:
Question 23: What is the most likely diagnosis of the lesion shown in the image below? 1091 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given image which shows a punched-out ulcer with regular margins on the plantar surface of 
the dry, crackled foot is suggestive of a neuropathic ulcer. Neuropathic ulcers occur as a result of repeated trauma to the insensitive part due to peripheral 
neuropathy. There is a lack of sensation over the pressure points, leading to unnoticed 
microtrauma, wounds or cuts which develop into an ulcer. Causes of neuropathic ulcers include 
diabetic neuropathy, B12 deficiency, alcoholism, hypothyroidism, leprosy, peripheral nerve injury, 
transverse myelitis and myelomeningocele. Other options: Option D: Tuberculous ulcers occur when a cold abscess from bone and joint tuberculosis breaks 
out on the surface. The most characteristic feature of this ulcer is its edge which is thin and

questions.question:
Question 24: A 68-year-old diabetic presented with a foot ulcer that he first noticed 1 month ago. The edges 
are irregular with sloped margins. The ulcer does not bleed to touch. Peripheral pulses are 
felt and an arterial doppler does not indicate a compromised blood flow. Which growth factor 
has been formulated and approved for treatment?
questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of a diabetic foot ulcer. At present, PDGF (platelet-derived 
growth factor)-BB is currently approved by the FDA for the treatment of diabetic foot ulcers. Application of recombinant human PDGF-BB in a gel suspension to these wounds increases the 
incidence of total healing and decreases healing time.

questions.question: Question 25: Which of the following procedures leaves a clean-contaminated wound?

options.b: Repair of an old duodenal perforation

questions.explanation:
1106 
Sold by @itachibot Elective procedures in uninfected respiratory, genital, urinary, and gastrointestinal tracts such as 
elective cholecystectomy produce clean-contaminated wounds. Option A: Thyroidectomy leaves a clean wound. Option B: Repair of an old duodenal perforation is a contaminated wound. Option D: Emergency appendectomy is usually performed in the setting of an inflamed appendix 
and results in a dirty surgical wound.

questions.question: Question 26: ASEPSIS wound scoring takes all of the following into consideration except:
questions.explanation:
ASEPSIS wound score does not take induration into consideration. Instead, the I in ASEPSIS 
stands for the isolation of bacteria from the wound. ASEPSIS wound score and Southampton wound score are used to determine the severity of the 
surgical site wound infection (SSI). ASEPSIS score includes: • Additional treatment • Antibiotics for wound infection • Drainage of pus under local anesthesia • Debridement of the wound under general anesthesia • Serous discharge • Erythema • Purulent exudate • Separation of deep tissue • Isolation of bacteria from the wound • Stay as inpatient prolonged over 14 days as a result of wound infection

questions.question: Question 27: Which of the following is used for wound infection grading?

options.a: Degree of contraction is dependant on amount of dermis in graft
options.b: Healing with abnormal pigmentation are more common.
options.d: Meshing grafts improve their ultimate cosmetic appearance

questions.explanation:
Southampton wound grading system is used to score the severity of wound site infection. Southampton wound grading system: • Grade 0 - Normal healing • Grade I - Normal healing with different grades of erythema • Grade II - Erythema with other signs of inflammation at different parts of the wound. • Grade III - Clear or serosanguinous discharge at different sites • Grade IV - Pus discharge Other options: 1107 
Sold by @itachibot Option A: American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) grading is used in pre-anesthetic checkups 
to assess a patient's physical health and fitness for anesthesia and surgery. Option B: Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome (SIRS) is a set of clinical criteria used to 
identify and monitor critically ill patients with high-grade burns, severe trauma, and other major 
surgeries. Option D: Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation II (APACHE II) is a scoring system 
used to assess the severity and predict the outcome of pancreatitis. 1108 
Sold by @itachibot Reconstructive Surgery
